Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: I sat at the dinner table, swirling my fork in mashed potatoes, half-listening as my stepdad suggested a Saturday hiking trip. My stepbrother’s eyes lit up, and my mom smiled, nudging me to join in. “It’ll be good for all of us,” she said, her voice hopeful. I wanted to say yes, to be part of this new family, to not be the odd one out. But my mind kept drifting to the Torah portion I’d been practicing for weeks. This Saturday, I was supposed to chant it at synagogue—a big deal for me and my community. My rabbi had reminded me how important it was to show up, to honor my commitment. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: the need to belong with my stepfamily, and the responsibility to my faith. My heart pounded as everyone looked at me, waiting for my answer, and I felt the tension coil tighter inside me, unsure which part of myself I’d have to let down.
